Act1Scene3Part1a.speaker: First Witch
Act1Scene3Part1a.text:
A sailor’s wife had chestnuts in her lap
And munched and munched and munched.
“Give me,” quoth I.

Act1Scene3Part1a.speaker: First Witch
First Witch
Act1Scene3Part1a.text:
But in a sieve I’ll thither sail,
And, like a rat without a tail,
I’ll do, I’ll do, and I’ll do.

Act1Scene3Part1a.speaker: First Witch
Act1Scene3Part1a.translation: A contraction of “thou art kind,” meaning “you are kind”

Act1Scene3Part1a.speaker: First Witch
Act1Scene3Part1a.text:
I myself have all the other,
And the very ports they blow;
All the quarters that they know
I’ th’ shipman’s card.

Act1Scene3Part1a.speaker: First Witch
Act1Scene3Part1a.text:
I’ll drain him dry as hay.
Sleep shall neither night nor day
Hang upon his penthouse lid.
He shall live a man forbid.

Act1Scene3Part1a.speaker: First Witch
Act1Scene3Part1a.text:
Weary sev’nnights, nine times nine,
Shall he dwindle, peak, and pine.
Though his bark cannot be lost,
Yet it shall be tempest-tossed.
Look what I have.

Act1Scene3Part1a.speaker: First Witch
Act1Scene3Part1a.text:
Here I have a pilot’s thumb,
Wracked as homeward he did come.

 - Drum within... -

Act1Scene3Part1a.speaker: Third Witch
Act1Scene3Part1a.text:
A drum, a drum!
Macbeth doth come.

Act1Scene3Part1a.speaker: The Witches
Act1Scene3Part1a.text:
The Weïrd Sisters, hand in hand,
 Posters of the sea and land,
Thus do go about, about,
Thrice to thine and thrice to mine.
And thrice again, to make up nine.
Peace, the charm’s wound up.
Act1Scene3Part1a.translation: The Weird Sisters (or witches) chant this incantation while preparing their brew. It’s part of their dark magic, and the repetition of the number nine has mystical significance.

Act1Scene3Part1a.speaker: Banquo
Act1Scene3Part1a.text: How far is ’t called to Forres? — What are these???
Act1Scene3Part1a.translation: Banquo is asking how far it is to Forres, where they are to meet with king Duncan. However this is cut short upon seeing these wicked witches.
